title: Your Child at 7: Milestones
author: WebMD Editorial Contributors

content: Many parents can’t help but wonder if their children are growing and developing at the right pace. Sometimes common milestones can be a helpful tool.
But remember that all children are different and special. Milestones are meant to be guidelines, not strict rules.
If you have specific questions about how your child is hitting a certain milestone associated with being 7, you should consult your family doctor or your child’s pediatrician .
Keep an eye out for these kinds of milestones:
bullets: Language and academic development
Social and emotional development

content_blocks.text: Many parents can’t help but wonder if their children are growing and developing at the right pace. Sometimes common milestones can be a helpful tool.
But remember that all children are different and special. Milestones are meant to be guidelines, not strict rules.
If you have specific questions about how your child is hitting a certain milestone associated with being 7, you should consult your family doctor or your child’s pediatrician .
Keep an eye out for these kinds of milestones:

sections.heading: Language and Education
content: A 7-year-old child, typically in second grade, normally will be developing more complex sentences as they grow.
bullets: They’ll learn to speak better and be able to follow a longer series of commands than they could at age 6. They should be able to be understood by everyone.
They have begun to see that some words have more than one meaning. That helps them understand jokes and puns and start verbally expressing a sense of humor.
Children in early school years can show fast growth in mental ability.

content_blocks.text: A 7-year-old child, typically in second grade, normally will be developing more complex sentences as they grow.

items: They’ll learn to speak better and be able to follow a longer series of commands than they could at age 6. They should be able to be understood by everyone.
They have begun to see that some words have more than one meaning. That helps them understand jokes and puns and start verbally expressing a sense of humor.
Children in early school years can show fast growth in mental ability.

content: By now, children:
Get to know your school administrators and your child’s teachers. Participate in homework assignments. If you think your 7-year-old is falling behind, stay calm but be on the lookout for:
bullets: Understand the concept of numbers
Know day from night, and left from right
Can tell time
Can repeat three numbers backward
Difficulty reading or other possible signs of disability
Something that’s bugging your child, like bullying
A mental health issue or stress

content_blocks.text: By now, children:
associated_bullets: Know day from night, and left from right

content_blocks.text: Get to know your school administrators and your child’s teachers. Participate in homework assignments. If you think your 7-year-old is falling behind, stay calm but be on the lookout for:
associated_bullets: Difficulty reading or other possible signs of disability
Something that’s bugging your child, like bullying
A mental health issue or stress

sections.heading: Development
bullets: Baby teeth will be falling out to make room for permanent teeth.
Kids in this age group generally grow about 2.5 inches a year and 4 to 7 pounds a year.
A sense of body image has begun.

Children in early school years also complain more about tummy aches, leg pains, and such. That might be because they’re becoming more aware of their bodies. Still, parents should check these complaints out to make sure there’s no injury or illness.

items: Baby teeth will be falling out to make room for permanent teeth.
Kids in this age group generally grow about 2.5 inches a year and 4 to 7 pounds a year.
A sense of body image has begun.

Children in early school years also complain more about tummy aches, leg pains, and such. That might be because they’re becoming more aware of their bodies. Still, parents should check these complaints out to make sure there’s no injury or illness.

content: Resist the urge to compare your child to others or to some “standard” you’ve heard about.
Your doctor should have a growth chart for your child. They will use that at each visit to see if your child's growth is following their curve.
Avoid making your kid eat more to reach some “standard” number about weight .
Remember that everyone is unique.

content_blocks.text: Resist the urge to compare your child to others or to some “standard” you’ve heard about.
Your doctor should have a growth chart for your child. They will use that at each visit to see if your child's growth is following their curve.
Avoid making your kid eat more to reach some “standard” number about weight .
Remember that everyone is unique.

sections.heading: Social, Emotional
bullets: From ages 6 to 8, kids are getting more and more independent from their parents. They will try to show how big they are, and do things that might be dangerous.
Peer acceptance becomes more important than before in the early school years. They are learning to cooperate and share.
Boys will tend to play with boys, and girls with girls.
Parents should let kids make their own choices about sports and toys -- what’s “for boys” or “for girls” and such. And keep a range of diverse, non-stereotypical examples around.
It’s about now that kids start to develop skills and attention spans and understand teamwork to start playing organized sports.
With growing language skills, kids get increasingly better at describing what has happened, what they feel, and what they think.
Lying, cheating, and stealing are to be expected somewhat in early school years. Kids are figuring out where they fit, the difference between right and wrong, and what’s acceptable.

items: From ages 6 to 8, kids are getting more and more independent from their parents. They will try to show how big they are, and do things that might be dangerous.
Peer acceptance becomes more important than before in the early school years. They are learning to cooperate and share.
Boys will tend to play with boys, and girls with girls.
Parents should let kids make their own choices about sports and toys -- what’s “for boys” or “for girls” and such. And keep a range of diverse, non-stereotypical examples around.
It’s about now that kids start to develop skills and attention spans and understand teamwork to start playing organized sports.
With growing language skills, kids get increasingly better at describing what has happened, what they feel, and what they think.
Lying, cheating, and stealing are to be expected somewhat in early school years. Kids are figuring out where they fit, the difference between right and wrong, and what’s acceptable.

sections.heading: More Ways Parents Can Help
bullets: Use steady time limits on video games, computer use, and TV. Make sure screen time doesn’t cut into physical play, enough sleep , and family communication time.
Help them to establish structure and routine with chores and school obligations.
Keep reading to your 7-year-old, and have them read to you.
Consider parental controls on computers and TV.
Give them rules for internet usage, such as not giving out personal information.
Make sure they stay safe around strangers and that they know theirs and your phone number and address, along with 911.
Don’t be afraid to talk to your kids about tough topics like peer pressure , violence, drug use, and sexuality. Find age-appropriate ways to answer questions without adding to confusion or fear.
Support your child’s self-esteem, and encourage them to have fun and express themselves.
Consider swimming lessons and fire safety training for your child.

Stanford Children’s Health: “The Growing Child: School-Age (6 to 12 Years).”
Healthy Children: “Gender Identity and Gender Confusion in Children,”
American Academy of Pediatrics: “New Recommendations for Children’s Media Use.”
meta_description: By age 7, your child should reach certain development milestones. Here are the milestones to watch for at age 7.
